725742f-d.title: Queens: 94th Street - Ditmars Boulevard
725742f-d.text:
94th Street, east side, south of Ditmars Boulevard, showing
in four views the J. I. Ranelye farmhouse of 1852. View ore
shows partiallv the above hnentioned street which was oricinally
known as Old Bowery Road. This house was demolished in May 1929.
Ieg 1908 it stood directlv in the center of 95th Street (old 38th
Street) about 208 ft. south of Ditrars Boulevard. ThUw house faces
north ad vas owned by A.Rapelve, 1880; C.P. Harris, 18'3-1891;
and C.H. Harris in u896. Across Jackson Mill Pond on the east
side of 94th Street, north of this house was located the T.B.
Jackson house and mill. Samuel Fish, son of Nathann Fish became
the owncr in 1715. In 1724 he purchased the adjoining mill from
the heirs of Jesse Kip. Bis son John (1719-1795) succeeded to
the paternal estate and mill at Fish Point. His dauchters Anna
(h 1748) and Sarah (b 1762) married Jacob and William Palmer
resrectively. Their brother Samuel (b 17S2- d 1854), a bachelor,
owned the paternal estate.
arch 1925
Views 223: March 19I3
View 4: Nay 1926.

725743f-a.title: Queens: 94th Street - Ditmars Boulevard
725743f-a.text:
94th Street, south from above Ditmars Boulevard, showing
the Rapelye houses (right) and the C. P. Harris House (left).
In the foreground is the Jaukson Mill Creek and the bridge
about 50 feet north of where Ditmars Boulevard was later cut
throuah. Grand Central Parkway now (1940) traverses this
foreground area from left to right. 94th Street, here, is
the former Old Bowery Road.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection  1923
MAY BE REPRODUC2D  Views 1,2,3

725724f-c.title: Queens: 94th Street - Ditmars Boulevard
725724f-c.text:
94th Street north from Ditmars Boulevard to Nineteenth
Avenue. The creek in the foreground is known as Jackson's
Aiill Pond. He operated a grext mill here in the middle of the
19th century. According to J. Riker Jr's. map of 1852 of
4ewtown, the one story building seen at the rimht is probably
Mear or on the site of the mill. The road extending to the
left beyond the creek is Old Bowery Road. The fourndation for
the mill was laid by Peter C. Luyster in 1668. The house in
the background of view No. three, looking south, is that of
Abraham Rapelye in 1852.
March 1923
View 3:  May 192E
View 2:  Nay 1926.
Eicene L. Armbruster Collection
MAY BE RT:PRODUCED.

725740f-a.title: Queens: 94th Street - Ditmars Boulevard
725740f-a.text:
94th Street (left), south from above Ditmars Boulevard,
showing, on high ground, the two Rapelye houses and barns
(right). In the foreground is 4ackson Mill Creek and the land
is part of the Rapelye farm. 94th Street is the former Old
Bowery Road. Ditmars Avenue was later cut through just below
the creek and Grand Central Parkway in the immediate foreground.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection  View 1: 1925
MAY BE REPRODUCED  Views 2,3: 1923
